page.title: 02Housing In Denaby Main
page.content: In 1967{Denaby}had been a mining village for about 100 years. Dwellings had been built as a ribbon-development plan,very close together, in order to house as many people as possible. Conisbrough Urban District Council decided on a slum-clearance programme which would involve about 4,000 houses and 10,000 people: this represented about 95% of the whole village. The existing houses and land had first to be purchased from the{National Coal {Board.}Important features of the 'new village' are: senior citizens' bungalows with gardens, disabled- persons' units, communal halls, shopping precincts, playing fields and a small ,industrial estate. This unique scheme was completed by the { {Doncaster Metropolitan Borough {Council}in 1980.
